Description: A tall jar of coarse red siltware pottery, with a rounded base, straight asymmetrical sides, a rounded shoulder and a short neck. The exterior is covered by a red slip. Both the core fabric and the slip contain many inclusions of fine grit, probably from sand. The irregularity of the body of the vessel and the variance in the rim diameter indicate carelessness in manufacture.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tell Dafana, Findspot 30, in a cell of the "Qasr" partly beneath the foundation of the northern part of the casemate building A
Curator's comments: This jar has been found with others of the same type, partly beneath the foundation of the large casemate building. The provenance from Findspot 39 as indicated in the Museum register is an error : the findspot number scratched onto one side is 30, in accordance with Petrie's publication (W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 54 § 53, pl. xxxiv, 23).
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 54 § 53, p. 64, 65, 66 § 61, pl. xxxiv, 23)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.29, table.1, p.94, p.105, p.134, p.193, pl.35)
